questions.prompt: In BG 14.1, what does Arjuna ask Krishna?
choices: About war tactics through independent material processes
Teach me about the three modes of nature and their effects
About diplomacy and worldly philosophical speculation
About governance and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Arjuna seeks to understand the three gunas and their influence.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.3, what is the great womb from which all beings are born?
choices: The earth and worldly philosophical speculation
My womb is the great Brahman beings are conceived in it
The sky and worldly philosophical speculation
The ocean and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Krishna is the source of all existence through His transcendental nature.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.4, what does Krishna describe about His creative function?
choices: I have no role through independent material processes
every forms are born from me the father
primarily matter creates through independent material processes
Creation is random through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Krishna and His material energy combine to manifest all existence.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.5 teach about the three modes?
choices: They do not exist through independent material processes
Sattva (goodness), rajas (passion) tamas (ignorance) bind the eternal soul
primarily one exists through independent material processes
They are temporary through independent material processes
questions.feedback: The three qualities are the basic constituents of material nature.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.6, what is the characteristic of sattva (goodness)?
choices: Brings darkness and worldly philosophical speculation
Pure, luminous free from sinfulness
Causes confusion and worldly philosophical speculation
Brings pain and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Sattva is the purest mode and leads toward spiritual elevation.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.7, what is the nature of rajas (passion)?
choices: It is peaceful through independent material processes
The embodiment of desire and attachment; causes action and craving
It brings knowledge through independent material processes
It is stagnant through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Passion creates restlessness and desire-driven action.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.8 teach about tamas (ignorance)?
choices: It is enlightening through independent material processes
Darkness, delusion, and laziness; binds the living being through illusion
It brings joy through independent material processes
It is spiritually advanced through independent material processes
questions.feedback: Ignorance is the most degrading mode, creating delusion and inertia.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.10, what happens when sattva predominates?
choices: One remains bound through independent material processes
The symptoms of purity appear; wisdom and good qualities manifest
Confusion increases and worldly philosophical speculation
Bondage strengthens and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Goodness illuminates consciousness and leads toward liberation.

questions.prompt: In BG 14.11, what are the symptoms of rajas predominance?
choices: Peace and knowledge through independent material processes
Fruitive activity, restlessness, craving, and endless desire
Lethargy and worldly philosophical speculation
Wisdom emerges and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Passion drives one toward endless pursuit of temporary goals.

questions.prompt: What does BG 14.12 teach about tamas predominance?
choices: Wisdom appears and worldly philosophical speculation
Darkness, delusion, negligence, and madness; one becomes bound
Joy increases and worldly philosophical speculation
Knowledge grows and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Ignorance creates a state of confusion and spiritual darkness.

questions.prompt: According to BG 14.13, what happens when one transcends the modes?
choices: One remains bound through independent material processes
One goes beyond birth, death, old age, and is liberated
One suffers more through independent material processes
One stagnates and worldly philosophical speculation
questions.feedback: Transcending the gunas is the gateway to permanent liberation.

One sees the same consciousness in every
Attached to results through independent material processes
Easily disturbed and worldly philosophical speculation

Continued suffering and worldly philosophical speculation
Knowledge of physical phenomena and external forms

every are equal through independent material processes
